title: Diabetic Ketoacidosis Mortality Prediction Model (DKA MPM) Score
description: Predicts in-hospital mortality in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis using clinical and laboratory parameters at presentation, 12 hours, and 24 hours

parameters.name: severe_comorbidities
parameters.description: Presence of severe comorbidities (immunosuppression, previous MI, COPD, cirrhosis, CHF, and/or previous stroke)

parameters.name: insulin_over_50_units
parameters.description: More than 50 units of regular insulin required over first 12 hours

parameters.name: glucose_over_300_at_12h
parameters.description: Serum glucose > 300 mg/dL (16.7 mmol/L) after 12 hours

parameters.name: depressed_mental_state_24h
parameters.description: Depressed mental state at 24 hours after presentation (as determined by examiner)

parameters.name: fever_24h
parameters.description: Fever at 24 hours after presentation (axillary temperature ≥38°C / 100.4°F)

result.name: dka_mpm_score_result
result.description: DKA MPM Score for mortality prediction (0-25 points)

ranges.interpretation: Patients with DKA MPM Score 0-14 points have low risk of in-hospital mortality (0.86%). Standard DKA management and monitoring protocols are appropriate. These patients typically have good prognosis with appropriate treatment.

Patients with DKA MPM Score 15-18 points have high risk of in-hospital mortality (20.8%). Enhanced monitoring, aggressive management, and consideration for intensive care unit admission is recommended. Close monitoring of fluid balance, electrolytes, and mental status is crucial.

ranges.description: Very high risk of in-hospital mortality
ranges.interpretation: Patients with DKA MPM Score 19-25 points have very high risk of in-hospital mortality (93.3%). Immediate intensive care unit admission, aggressive resuscitation, and specialized multidisciplinary management are indicated. Consider early family discussions regarding prognosis and goals of care.

clinical_applications: Risk stratification of patients with diabetic ketoacidosis
Guiding intensity of monitoring and care in DKA patients
Assisting in ICU admission decisions for DKA patients
Prognostic counseling for patients and families
Quality improvement initiatives in DKA management

scoring_methodology.calculation: Sum of all parameter points based on presence/absence of risk factors
scoring_methodology.timing: Assessment at presentation (0h), 12 hours, and 24 hours after presentation
scoring_methodology.risk_categories: Low risk (0-14), High risk (15-18), Very high risk (19-25)

limitations: Not externally validated - use with caution
Not intended for routine patient disposition decisions
APACHE II Score may be a better mortality predictor
Limited to adult patients with confirmed DKA diagnosis
Requires assessment at multiple time points (0h, 12h, 24h)
Inter-observer variability in assessment of mental state
contraindications: Use as sole basis for clinical decision-making

validation.evidence_basis: Single-center retrospective study - not externally validated

references: Efstathiou SP, Tsiakou AG, Tsioulos DI, et al. A mortality prediction model in diabetic ketoacidosis. Clin Endocrinol (Oxf). 2002;57(5):595-601. doi: 10.1046/j.1365-2265.2002.01636.x.
Kitabchi AE, Umpierrez GE, Miles JM, Fisher JN. Hyperglycemic crises in adult patients with diabetes. Diabetes Care. 2009;32(7):1335-1343. doi: 10.2337/dc09-9032.
Dhatariya KK, Glaser NS, Codner E, Umpierrez GE. Diabetic ketoacidosis. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 2020;6(1):40. doi: 10.1038/s41572-020-0165-1.
formula: DKA MPM Score = (Severe comorbidities × 6) + (pH < 7.0 × 4) + (>50 units insulin in 12h × 4) + (Glucose >300 mg/dL at 12h × 4) + (Depressed mental state at 24h × 4) + (Fever at 24h × 3)
notes: Score requires assessment at three time points: presentation, 12 hours, and 24 hours
Severe comorbidities include immunosuppression, previous MI, COPD, cirrhosis, CHF, and/or previous stroke
pH measurement should be arterial blood gas
Regular insulin requirement includes only regular insulin, not long-acting forms
Glucose measurement at 12 hours should be serum glucose
Mental state assessment is subjective and requires clinical judgment
Fever is defined as axillary temperature ≥38°C (100.4°F)
Not externally validated - use clinical judgment in conjunction with score
Consider APACHE II score as alternative mortality predictor
Not intended as sole basis for clinical decision-making
